document.docAuthor: De, Bruno A. S. & Vanin, Sergio A.
document.masterDocTitle: Systematic revision and morphological phylogenetic analysis of Anchylorhynchus Schoenherr, 1836 (Coleoptera, Curculionidae: Derelomini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Systematic revision and morphological phylogenetic analysis of Anchylorhynchus Schoenherr, 1836 (Coleoptera, Curculionidae: Derelomini)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Anchylorhynchus variabilis Gyllenhal in Schoenherr, 1836:451
(description); Castelnau, 1850:346 (cat.); Lacordaire, 1863:520 (cat.); Sherborn, 1931:6793 (cat.); Vaurie, 1954:40 , Figs. 1 e 3I (revision); Blackwelder, 1947:827 (cat.); Viana, 1975: 29 , Figs. 4 , 7 , 8 e 9 (revision); Wibmer & O’Brien, 1986:196 (cat.); Franz, 2006:224 (phylogeny);
Silva et al., 2012:1
(biology). Holotype : Male; Brazil ; Klug. Deposited in NHRM accession NHRS-JLKB 000027290, images examined.

Ancylorrhynchus mutabilis connata Voss, 1943
(description in key). Holotype not examined.
Redescription. Male: Body size (length of elytra + pronotum) 5.5–8.7 mm .

Head: Rostrum 1.3–1.4 times as long as pronotum; 1.3–1.4 times wider at apex than at base; with integument brown to black; with seven longitudinal carinae (including a pair along scrobes), distinct throughout their length; scrobes parallel to rostrum; apex covered by microsetae; areas between dorsal carinae covered by yellowish scales, narrow to setiform at base and setiform at the apex of rostrum, directed toward the central carina. Eyes 1.3–1.4 times as high as wide; 0.6–0.6 times more separated above than below. Head integument black or brown, similar to or darker than rostrum; covered by large scales only around the eyes and on the sides and microsetae elsewhere; scales usually black to dark brown, sometimes yellow on the sides and above eyes, directed to a point basal to the inter-ocular fovea. Antennae with scape straight, barely reaching anterior eye margin; funicle: antennomere I of funicle only slightly wider than II, II longer than I and about 2 times as long as III, VI as wide as long and narrower than club; club about as long as antennomeres IV–VI of the funicle. Left mandible slightly sinuate at outer margin; with one dorsal seta; outer tooth forming a sharp angle with the mandible margin, with rounded apex; inner tooth well-developed; molar region straight. Left maxilla with stipes strongly elongate, with a long ventral seta; galeolacinial complex almost reaching the apex of palpomere I; palpiger with transverse ventral region, dorsal region with an acute angle at base; palpomere I with two apical setae longer than the length of palpomere I; palpomere II longer than palpomere I. Labium prementum distinctively narrower than postmentum, about 1.5 times as wide as long, lateral margins divergent in median region, angled in lateral-apical region, with two oblique rows of setae in dorsal region; ligula shorter than half of the length of prementum; palps separated by about the width of palpomere I; palpomere I transverse; palpomere II shorter than palpomere III; palpomere III with one lateral seta.

Thorax: Pronotum width at base 1.6–1.8 times pronotum length; base not lobed at middle; lateral margins in dorsal view convergent and regularly curved from base to apex, without apical constriction; integument uniformly brown or black only under black scales; covered by black scales in a longitudinal median band and on the lateralapical regions, and yellow to orange scales elsewhere; scales on disk directed to the center or to the apex. Profemur approximately 3 times as long as wide; dorsal margin with curvature about as pronounced as ventral margin; tooth well-defined; about 3 times as wide as protibia. Protarsus tarsomere I about as long as tarsomere III; tarsomeres I and II longer than wide; with short and dense setae on the ventral surface, without sparse and long setae on the sides. Scutellum 0.7–0.9 times longer than wide; integument black; scales yellowish. Elytra 1.5–1.7 times wider than pronotum; 1.4–1.5 times longer than wide; 3.7–4.0 times longer than pronotum; humeri rounded; lateral margins distinctively wider at middle; dorsal region with yellowish scales; epipleura generally with a distinct inflexion on interval IX, but sometimes with a weak inflexion, covered by yellowish or dark scales. Ventral region of thorac integument yellowish to black; setae white to pale yellow, distinctively lighter than those in pronotum. Hypomeron scales setiform. Prosternum length 0.8–1.0 times the width of coxae; postocular lobes indistinct, with apical-lateral margin of prothorax regularly curved to slightly sinuate; covered by sparse setae. Metepisternum entirely covered by dense setae. Metasternum central concavity distinct; with long setae in the center.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 14. Habitus of species of
Anchylorhynchus
(continued). Scales: 1 mm. A
A. variabilis
(female). B–C
A. vittipennis
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Abdomen: Ventrites III–V covered by erect setae. Aedeagus 2–2.5 times as long as wide; about 4 times as long as high; distinctly wider at opening; with a bilobed anterior process; ventral plate strongly sclerotized, extending to approximately 0.4 times the length of apodemes. Apodemes about 2.5 times as long as aedeagus. Endophallus with one pair of membranous pockets containing microtrichae next to the basal sclerite and membranous and slightly sclerotized area anterior to the basal sclerite; with microtrichae of the apical region not organized in bands.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 15. Prosterna of species of
Anchylorhynchus
, ventral view. Scales: 500 µm. A
A. bicarinatus
. B
A. camposi
. C
A. chrysomeloides
. D
A. variabilis
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female: Body size 5.1–7.4 mm . Rostrum 1.2–1.4 times longer than pronotum; width at apex 1.3–1.5 times width at base. Eyes 1.2–1.4 times as high as wide; 0.5–0.7 times more separated above than below. Pronotum 1.6–1.7 times as wide at base as long. Prosternum length 0.9–1.0 times the coxal width. Scutellum 0.8–0.9 times as long as wide. Elytra 1.6–1.8 times as wide as pronotum; 1.4–1.5 times as long as wide; 4.0–4.2 times as long as pronotum; color patterns either same as males ( Figure 13H ) or with variously developed transverse black bands, including entirely black (see Figures 13 I–L, 14A). Ventrites III–V with recumbent setae. Ventrites III and IV with posterior retraction strongly sinuate and reaching the middle of the segment.

Remarks. This species is easily diagnosed by the presence of elongate setae, instead of scales, in all ventral surfaces and also in the epipleura ( Figures 13 H–L, 14A, 15D, 16D, 19F). All males have yellow elytra ( Figure 13H ), while females show different patterns of black and yellow scales ( Figures 13 I–L, 14A). Females with completely yellow elytra are usually rare but increase in frequency near the southern limit of the species distribution.

Geographical Distribution. This species is found in forests and open habitats from the central-southern Brazil to eastern Argentina ( Figure 24 ). Some specimens from the Dirings collection (MZSP) are labelled as Carquejo, Ceará , Brazil , a locality much farther north than the others known for the species or for its known host plant. S. A. Vanin has found similarly suspect records for species of Belidae from the same collection, with species typical of southeastern Brazil labelled as collected Carquejo, Ceará . Both cases are likely mistakes.

Host Plants.
Syagrus rommanzoffiana (Cham.) Glassman
(vouchers SPF B.A.S. Medeiros 88, 113) and
Butia odorata (Barb. Rodr.) Noblick.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 16. Meso- and metathorax of species of
Anchylorhynchus
, lateral view. Scales: 500 µm. A
A. camposi
. B
A. burmeisteri
. C
A. multisquamis
. D
A. variabilis
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Bondar (1943a) received material from several collaborators (R. Lange, J. Moure, A. Maller and F. Plaumann) from southern Brazil of specimens of
A. variabilis
obtained from a palm identified as
Cocos romanzoffiana Chamiso
, a junior synonym of
Syagrus rommanzoffiana (Cham.) Glassman. Viana (1975)
states the species is found in flowers of “pindo (
Cocos romanzoffiana Chamiso
)”, which is a common name used both for
Syagrus romanzoffiana
and
Butia odorata (Barb. Rodr.) Noblick. Bondar (1941a)
received specimens from Juan Bosq, in Argentina , collected from
Cocos capitata Mart.
(a junior synonym of
Butia odorata
).
Butia odorata
and
Syagrus romanzoffiana
are known to produce natural hybrids where they co-occur (
Lorenzi et al. 2010
), and it is possible that they also share this species of pollinator. Finally,
Silva et al. (2012)
reared
A. variabilis
from seeds of
S. romanzoffiana in Florianópolis
, Brazil and we collected
A. variabilis
from
Syagrus romanzoffiana
in several localities.

Examined Specimens. Type Material.
BRAZIL .
No region :
No locality, Klug , no date ( ♂ holotype
Anchylorhynchus variabilis
NHRS); illegible, Klug, no date ( ♀ holotype
Anchylorhynchus mutabilis
NHRS)
.
